head.hi: Querying and Analyzing Image Annotations in IMMARKUS and X-MARKUS

div.p: All annotation data and metadata of a given image corpus can be viewed, filtered, and queried in the knowledge graph. The default view (Hierarchy and Annotation mode) displays all images (blue nodes) and entity or tag classes (green nodes), connected by blue edges that indicate which entities or tags have been used to annotate which images. Users can adjust the display by clicking the settings icon at the bottom right corner of the screen, allowing them to change how data is shown — for example, hiding text labels for better visibility. To run a query, users can click the magnifying glass icon (circled in blue in Figure 20) to open the graph search dialogue box and enter search conditions. Figure 20 shows a query for images with annotations of walls depicted in interlocking layered rectangular shapes on maps preserved in Shandong gazetteers, spanning the Ming to the Qing dynasties. In the central panel, blue nodes indicate all images matching the query criteria. Selecting a specific image (marked with an orange circle) reveals the entity classes used in the annotation of the selected image as connected green nodes. Annotations for the selected image are also listed in the right-hand panel, from where users can move to the source image in the Image Gallery, explore relationship annotations, or edit the image’s metadata.

The query results––including annotations, metadata (user-supplied or imported through IIIF), and relations between annotations––can be exported in JSON for further analysis or, along with image snippets, in CSV. The exported data can, in the example of city wall maps, be used to visualize changes in cartographic conventions for depicting wall layouts and materials across different periods and regions. The data obtained from queries like the one displayed in Figure 20 yields the insight that the use of bricks in city walls appeared in gazetteer map symbology from the early seventeenth century onwards, reflecting growing attention to materiality . The IMMARKUS wiki include a fuller explanation of all functionality in the knowledge graph .

figure.head: Knowledge graph in IMMARKUS displaying the results of a query for images of county walls depicted with brick layout in county gazetteers from Shandong Province from the Ming to the Qing dynasties (labels and unconnected nodes hidden). Annotation by Wang Ran (KU Leuven).
figure.figDesc: IMMARKUS knowledge graph displaying query results in a graph and with annotations for a selected node shown on the right panel.

div.p: The knowledge graph in IMMARKUS offers powerful querying options, but it is limited to one project. In order to query across image annotation projects (for example, historical maps, stelae, rubbings, archeological diagrams, and photographs of infrastructural objects) or to query across textual and image datasets we designed X-MARKUS to detect shared entity types and entity properties as well as shared metadata fields in different datasets. We first identified shared entities or tags, shared external authorities in properties, and shared metadata fields in the ontologies described in the Appendix. We then used this as the basis for the complex task of visualizing relationships between different and cross-media datasets, thus making information about the same objects or the same location, or from the same source or author more easily discoverable. The photographic images of stone stelae and rubbings described above on one hand, and the event annotation data discussed in sections two on the other, provide a first example. In this case, the source metadata (title, place and place id, infrastructure type, year, author and author id, etc.) and the main object name and id can be linked to data and metadata in the event annotation of the transcribed text included in one or more local gazetteers. The inscription text shown above in Figures 5-6 was likely transcribed into the county gazetteer from the stele represented in the rubbing shown in Figures 16-17; stelae and transcription can in this case be linked through their metadata. Collecting and developing a data model for stone stelae and rubbings ensures that other elements such as stone size and format, its placement, the layout and font size of textual elements, decorations, front and back inscriptions with, for example, the names and social roles of people often not included in the transcriptions of stelae in local gazetteers offer additional inroads into the social history of infrastructures (De Weerdt et al. under review). In the design of X-MARKUS, shared metadata across different sources can be matched through multiple conditioned queries within a combined image and text corpus. For instance, a query might search for a piece title in a textual source and a stele title in an image source, while also requiring that the author’s identifier in external authority databases (CBDB ID 67470) is the same in both sources. The query yields a filtered network graph, as shown in Figure 21, where sources that meet the query criteria are displayed along with the features extracted from their annotations. With the relevant objects displayed in the graph, additional research can be performed on their similarities and differences. For example, the differences between the stele text transcribed in the annotation of the image and the gazetteer text can be easily researched with text comparison algorithms like PARALLELLS .

For example, “city_wall” and its various parts are annotated across events. div.p: Lest this example is still too text-oriented, Figure 22 offers an example of how archeological diagrams, historical maps, and texts can be made discoverable in the same environment. When annotating the wall complexes of Yangzhou as documented in archaeological report diagrams, we used the same entity classes and properties as those used in textual inscriptions related to walls –– such as object (wall) name, material, dimensions, and TGAZ ID (indicating the location of the historical jurisdiction). Most of these entities and properties are also used in the annotation of historical city and regional maps.

The graph visualizes six matching sources: the inscription text (Figure 4; red circle on the left), three archaeological diagrams (three green squares at the top right), and two historical maps from local and IIIF sources (green squares at the bottom right). Each image source or event is connected by solid edges with annotated features (blue circles), which are linked by dashed edges to their parent entities (purple circles). All dashed edges represent hierarchical relationships, either among features (purple and blue nodes) or within the structure of the source (pink and green nodes). div.p: The use of these entity or tag classes and the same external authorities for their properties allows us to call up annotations added to sources in different media and compare the information, arguments, and perspectives expressed in them. It allows us to assess what may have been unknown or left out in textual accounts that often lack information about early foundations. Conversely, it also allows us to examine how archeologists select and selectively interpret historical accounts. Overall, it is a step forward in the direction of the mapping out of the poor state of the archeology of infrastructure (Wilkinson 2018). The link with maps on which color and pattern are sometimes used to represent materials similarly allows for the comparison of materials identified and represented on stratigraphic diagrams or the representation thereof in infrastructural events in gazetteer texts.

In sum, the logic of contextual annotation in COMARKUS and image annotation in IMMARKUS is very similar, with the image selections drawn by a user serving as the equivalent of a contextual or event annotation. The image selection serves as the space within which entities and their properties are grouped together. Whereas in contextual annotation, an event or cluster structures entities and their ids and acquires these as attributes, in image annotation an image snippet acquires an entity and its properties as attributes. The knowledge graph function in X-MARKUS builds on this shared logic to identify and link common features and their hierarchical structure across text and image sources, enabling integrated research and comparison.

div.head: Conclusion: Contextualizing data through annotation and the creation of contexts in platform design
div.p: In the design of COMARKUS and IMMARKUS we have sought to offer a set of methods that allow researchers to contextualize entities and tagged content and thus create contextualized data. Annotation in COMARKUS and IMMARKUS starts from the modeling of source texts and images and steers the researcher from simple tagging towards structuring annotations into higher-order entities with properties that capture semantic relationships as she reads them in texts and images.

As we have illustrated on the basis of the creation of an event-based dataset of material infrastructures, this has allowed us to lay the foundation for an entirely new way to interpret the history of infrastructures. As digital historians and digital humanists we have sought to contextualize inscriptional and other sources in ways that allow us to reinterpret the social and political construction of infrastructures alongside the demolition, repair, and failures at different scales and in relation with environmental, demographic, military, and political conditions. By examining social events of infrastructural history and by reading data from textual inscriptions in the context of data created from material objects, archeological diagrams, and maps we are also prompted to reflect on the situatedness of each of the source types and genres included in our analysis. Figure 23 presents our design for the digital historical data journey in a flow chart — mapping the stages from source selection and corpora curation to data modelling, annotation, and integration across media and platforms, including feedback loops for the use of AI, at this stage mainly in entity, event, and image annotation and data analysis, but this is extensible to all stages.

figure.head: Flow chart illustrating the digital historical data journey from source selection, corpus curation, modelling and annotation, via text and image platforms, to the integration of machine learning tasks, and, cross-media annotation analysis. Designed by Dawn Zhuang and Xi Wangzhi (KU Leuven).
figure.figDesc: Flow chart of the data processing workflow outlining this study’s methodological framework.

div.p: To make good use of the methods presented here also requires the reading and analysis of the data resulting from contextual annotation in an environment that maximizes contextual reading opportunities. Texts annotated in ENTMARKUS and COMARKUS can be transformed into textual databases in X-MARKUS with tagged content, metadata, and relations between entities and tags brought into view as filters, and free form comments providing the kind of free annotation environment that is part of the humanities scholarly habitus . Further contextualization is offered by the option to define different operations on entities linked to external authorities, most notably the option to create spatial layers and network tables and visualizations, and examine the resulting data in a range of quantitative infographs, with datapoints hyperlinked to the annotated source texts. MUNDa infographs allow the user to interpret attributes in context, including absence of information for each record in its information displays. Thus, to examine labor, material, or action causes in particular types of events, the percentage of records for which no such information is available is also shown. Spatial layers can be further examined against existing historical spatial and other layers. Data can be exported in XML, CSV, and KML formats.

IMMARKUS was initially designed to facilitate the creation of project-specific image databases with similar functionality and, through the integration of IMMARKUS data in X-MARKUS, to facilitate contextualization across media and across text and graphic genres. By investing in cross-media methodological design, we have been able to go further than first anticipated. We are comparing and correlating the spread of the use and representation of materials such as brick not only in texts, but also in symbology of county maps from the Song through the Qing dynasties (Lee under review a). We can write a better-informed social history of infrastructural projects by comparing social and political actors in texts transcribed in gazetteers to the texts and layout of infrastructural stelae and rubbings and, in this way, set out their different social and political profiles .

Nevertheless, as we stated in the introduction, contextualization remains an unfulfilled mission and a moving target. Much context is already dropped when selecting a particular rendition of a text, object or graphic for analysis. In our own project, we see more room and need for historians to try and represent the full dimensionality of their sources, including not only their location in space and time, but also their transformation and the transformation of their relations to other sources . Similarly, the combination of text- and image-based data in data visualization and analysis remains a challenge, one that will hopefully open up new possibilities for reading, analyzing, and interpreting primary texts, graphic representations of historical objects, and secondary constructions together.

div.head: Appendix
div.p: This appendix expands on the RDF (Resource Description Framework) ontological framework introduced in the main text. It explains how the text annotation model in COMARKUS and the image annotation model in IMMARKUS are formalized, extended, and integrated. The adapted ontology enables inscription texts and historical maps to be represented in a unified semantic environment. It aligns shared entities and relationships across different annotation models and supports the design of an information retrieval platform for cross-domain queries and discovery.

figure.head: Integrated ontology model showing aligned entity classes across text and image annotation schemas. Shared classes including main infrastructure objects, their components, persons, places, and temporal markers serve as linking nodes, enabling integration across annotations and metadata from diverse sources.
figure.figDesc: Ontology diagram of linked text and image annotation models where the connections reflect the study’s integrated data design.

div.p: In COMARKUS and IMMARKUS, annotations are created through different workflows and based on distinct data models. These differences reflect the nature of the source materials, which often present complementary perspectives on the same entities. These entities include infrastructures and their components, locations and time periods, and individuals. A key feature of our approach is to make these correspondences explicit and to align them semantically. To achieve this, we translate entity classes and their relationships into RDF triples (subject–predicate–object), creating a unified ontological layer across both annotation models. Beyond expressing equivalent entities in a consistent and interoperable format, the ontology incorporates standard vocabularies to ensure a stable and extensible conceptual foundation. These include CIDOC CRM for cultural heritage entities and events, Dublin Core Terms for bibliographic and authorship metadata, and the W3C Time Ontology for temporal concepts. Where necessary, we extend the model using a custom namespace, reginfra, to cover domain-specific concepts not addressed in existing standards. This integrated design constitutes the foundation for the retrieval and analysis platforms we have developed, which rely on these semantic links to support meaningful cross-domain exploration.

head.hi: Integrating Text and Image Annotation Models

div.p: The left side of Figure 24 shows how the event annotation model translates into RDF triples. Each event, as the core concept in this ontology, is modeled as a reginfra:event instance. This instance serves as a central node connecting all relevant information: event attributes (type, start and end time, duration, location, cause, cost, and labor); the physical infrastructure and its components, along with the features and dimensions affected by the event; the individuals or social groups involved and their roles (initiator, sponsor, beneficiary); and the source material metadata covering spatial and temporal context as well as authorship details.

The representation of RDF triples for the image annotation model is shown on the right side of Figure 24. Following the same naming conventions used in the text annotation ontology, for example, reginfra:object_main and reginfra:object_part, the core element in this model is the reginfra:annotated_shape instance. It links to all other aspects of the annotation: the visual characteristics of the shape, including texture, color, and descriptors; the physical infrastructure, its components, or environmental features that the shape represents; spatial relationships both between infrastructure elements and between infrastructure and their surroundings; and metadata from the source material, including spatial and temporal context and authorship information.

Together, the two sides of Figure 24 demonstrate how the two models are integrated through shared entity classes (outlined in orange) and consistent naming conventions across both annotation domains. This integration allows an event described in inscriptions to be linked to a historical map when both refer to the same physical infrastructure. Through the integrated ontology, such links can also be established via shared time, location, or individuals in authorship. Together, these connections bring together different sources about the same subject and help build richer historical, geographic, and social contexts. This ontological framework also enables the X-MARKUS platform to bring together textual, visual, and linked data into a unified, navigable knowledge space.

Vocabulary terms referenced from existing ontologies are quoted directly from their URIs; therefore, variations in naming conventions reflect the original styles of those sources.
